The Baltimore Museum of Art
will present a major exhibition
of the work of "realist" Paul
Klee, under the auspices of the
Guggenheim Museum of New
York, and the Pasadena Art Museum of California.
The showing, entitled "Paul
Klee, a Retrospective Exhibition," will be held at the Museum trom- October 24 to November 19. Over 150 works dating
from 1901 to 1940 will be featured including oils, water colors, gouaches, drawings, prints,
and paintings-on-glass, as well
as his characteristic works in
mixed media technique. This is
the most comprehensive Klee exhibition ever presented in Baltimore.
The exhibition itself is comprised of works drawn from private collections, museums, and
dealers both in this conutry and
abroad. Two of the foremost
lenders are Felix Klee, son of
the artist, and the Paul Klee
Foundation of Berne, Switzerland.
Many Stages
Klee, while basically a realist,
was associated with several
movements, and his style was
varied. The exhibition closely
follows his various stages, from
his early attempts in black and
white to later ones in full color,
and clearly shows the effect of
his life on his works.
Klee himself said that "the
purpose of art is not to render
the visible, but rather to make
visible," and expresses his subjective point of view through
the use of an almost primitive
style, ciphers, formulas and
scientific symbols to expand the
vivid visual language which he
employed.
Musical terms often appear,
as in Fugue in Red (1921), and
the presence of musical forms
—harmonies, rhythms, and measured counterpoints—brings a dynamic balance to his work. Music permeates each of Klee's
pictures as it permeated his entire life.

father's works, "his dream-andfairytale motifs exude magic
and, above all, a delicate atmosphere which ensnares us to this

Vietnam 1967
A human life is hard to measure. The United States
was founded on the idea of "the infinite worth of one
human life." America can now say that over 15,000 lives
have been given in the name of democracy in Vietnam.
A lot has been said, but little has been done. There
must come a time in all foreign policy when the price of
goal attainment is no longer in proportion to tre goal.
We have far passed that point. What is even more disturbing is that the goals were never there. We are told
that LBJ and the Pentagon are trying to "sell this war
to the people." The very use of this phrase is odious
and cruel—and yet indicative of the situation.
The Hawks have had the last bone thrown to them.
We now sit and wait to see what comes after Con Thien.
One can see the scene at the Chief of Staffs' Headquarters as the markers are moved on the map. These tombstones are but toys in the nauseating parlor game that
LBJ is playing.
Walter Cronkite tells us_ that American soldiers are
cutting ears off Viet Cong corpses to keep as momentoes.
Perhaps Vietnamese indulge in similar atrocities, but
such behavior from Americans is horrendous. It is this
behavior, this sickness, that LBJ is personally responsible for as he continues to make a large part of the
American population puke.
There is a march on Washington next week, maybe
something can be said. In the meantime count up your
(lead as someone has in the following letter.
Dear President Johnson:
This is the fifth letter we've written since June on
the subject of Vietnam. Each of the first four came on
the occasion of the death of one of our high school buddies, and each of them, in case your memory lapses, was
a humanitarian plea to terminate the atrocities there,
with the youth of America in mind. With all due respect to your office, we suspect that our plebeian and
perhaps pathetic letters never really reached your attention but were rather glanced at and discarded by one of
your subordinates. So this time we are trying a new tack.
In all humbleness we suggest that perhaps you
might take a small trip to South Vietnam. No don't send
Goldberg or Rusk or McKeldin. Go by yourself. After
all, this is your war and you must have some interest,
whether intellectual or sadistic, in its progress. It is possible that your advisers are misinformed or, though this
is hard to believe, that they are attempting to keep some
of the facts from your knowledge. We have so much at
stake, why not give the place a once-over?
Go to Saigon and see what our great American Way
of Life has done to their culture. Watch the starving,
homeless refugees cowtowing to every soldier they see,
degrading themselves for a coin, offering their daughters for bread or some coffee. See them standing in the
marketplaces, all speaking English and smoking their
Luckies, selling girly magazines and frankfurters and
Coca-Cola. Take a look at what the Viet Cong terrorists
have done to the landscape and take note of the condition of what used to be the most impressive city in Southeast Asia. And talk to the people—see what their opinions of their deliverers are, see how much they approve
of our aid program. Go to our "rehabilitation centers"
and find out for yourself just why Eichmann and his
cohorts were hung.
Sneak a ride on one of our 11-52's and watch what
our "limited capacity" bombs can do to bridges and
factories. And schools and homes. And people. Bring
along binoculars too, as they add greatly to the view.
Take a good look at the lunar-like surface of the demilitarized zone and note that nothing is moving. That will
probably please you.
Wander through one of the hospitals and fill your
cowboy eyes with the sight of mangled bodies, dead and
dying civilians, napalm-burnt children and legless marines. Talk to the doctors and find out how many hundreds are left to die simply because of the overwhelming numbers of wounded. Think of Lynda's fiance and
Rusk's son-in-law—perhaps they will be killed, too. Will
you be able to shrug off the tears then?
Spend a few days at Con Thien or Hill 881. Find
out what it is like to clear out the swamp of 35,000
guerillas. See how it feels to lie face down in the bloodstained mud listening to shells expolding and men
screaming. Lie there, quaking in silent terror, and wonder whether God gives a damn. Listen to what the men
think of you and our great arsenal of democracy. Finally, meet a 14-year-old North Vietnamese soldier in the
underbrush and kill him. See how you like that.
Why don't you give it a try? You can always leave
if you don't like it. While you are there, though, give
the boys our love—they certainly need it.

The art of Hieronimus is to
be read and not looked at. For

stray animals are his environment. The artist's apartmentstudio is a managerie of posters,
books, sketches and such oddities as a coffin and a modern
scarecrow.

Sitting cross-legged on a cushion, the red-beared Hieronimus
removed
his bright orange
and blue jacket and proceeded
to tell of the tragedy that America was facing. He sadly told of
the death of our country in a
war against Red China and a
race war between black and
white. The pessimism of the artist is so strong that it dominates
every aspect of his works.
His apartment-studio contains
a number of works that have
never been display-d and may
never be. His sculptures are as-

semblages of the various symbols of America's decadence. His
modern scarecrow is actually the
new Messiah whom Hieronimus says will come though he is
not sure when. Covered with
scores of message buttons, the
sculpture depicts what is wrong
with America and why she is
doomed.
Coke and Chiquita
America is decadent according
to Hieronimus. The great symbols of America have become
Coca-Cola, Chiquita Banana,General Motors and the Almighty
Dollar. All of these are the major
progenitors of American imperialism.
Without a doubt, the most
shocking work the artist has
done is a coffin. Quietly sitting
in his kitchen, the coffin is the
symbol of a dying America. Coke
bottle caps lie on the top of the
coffin and on the outside he has
placed an American Express
sign. "Yes, we're dying that fast,"
Hieronimus said looking sadly
at his work.
Hieronimus lives across the

street from a large number of
Negroes. "It took quite a long
time before they came to trust
me in spite of the color of my
skin. But now we are very
friendly and I have come to
understand their hopelessness."

people, he has gained a keen
sense of the racial tragedy in our
country. The young artist claims
that only the presence of numerous FBI agents prevented racial riots in Baltimore this summer. He emphasized, however,
that the danger has not been allayed. Baltimore, according to
Hieronimus, will soon be engulfed in riots as will the rest
of the country.
The tragedy of Robert Hie
imus is that his predictions
may very well come true. War
with China is definitely within
the realm of possibility in light
of our Vietnam policy. The possibility of a race war within this
country, is equally terrifying and
possible.
